In this session we will be discussing from the 6th verse of the 12th chapter of the 1st canto of Srimad Bhagavatam.
Kimte Kama Suras Parha Mukunda Manasodvijaha Adhijakhrur Mudham Ragnaha Shuditasya Yathetare
The meaning of this verse is, O Brahmanas, the opulence of the king was so enchanting that the denizens of heaven aspired for it.
But because he, the king, Yudhishthira, was absorbed in the service of the king,
nothing could satisfy him except the lord's service.
So this clearly explains the position of a pure devotee,
even though he may be emperor of this world,
with opulences which are able to bewilder even the heavenly residents,
even such opulences cannot bewilder a pure devotee,
because the pure devotee's mind is fully absorbed in devotional service to Krishna.
So Srila Prabhupada explains very nicely in the purport,
there are two things in the world which can satisfy living beings, this world.
When one is materially engrossed, he is satisfied only by sense gratification.
But when one is liberated from the conditions of the material modes,
he is satisfied only by rendering loving service for the satisfaction of the lord.
This means that the living being is constitutionally a servitor.
The way we are made.
The way we are made.
The way we are made.
The way we are made.
Constitutionally means the way we are made.
We are meant to simply serve, serve, serve.
And we are never the one who is served.
Krishna is the only one who is always served by everyone else.
Everyone else is a servant, a servitor.
Being illusioned by the conditions of the external energy, material energy,
illusory energy, maya,
one falsely thinks himself to be the served,
but actually he is not served.
He is servant of the senses like lust, desire, anger, avarice, pride, madness, and intolerance.
Even people who are very, very powerful,
very rich, very nicely educated, very influential,
but ultimately they are all servant of their senses.
When it comes to them becoming victim of lust, desire, anger, pride, madness, intolerance,
they cannot control themselves.
When one is in his proper senses by attainment of spiritual knowledge,
he realizes that he is not the master of the material world,
but is only a servant of the senses.
To realize this requires spiritual understanding.
At that time, that is when one comes to understand his position as a servant,
as a saint.
He begs for the service of the Lord, and thus becomes happy,
without being illusioned by so called material happiness.
Material happiness is not real happiness.
Happiness in the service of Krishna is real happiness.

The world is dissatisfied because there is no sufficient food or no sufficient shelter, defense, and objects of sense gratification.
Ahara, nidra, bhaya, maithu, namcha. These are four demands of the body. Every living entity's body demands these four things.
And people think there is some scarcity of one or more of these four things. That's why people are dissatisfied. But that's not the real fact.
This is called illusion. To think that people are dissatisfied because of the scarcity of one of these four things, ahara, nidra, bhaya, maithu, namcha, is actually due to illusion.
When the living being is hungry for spiritual satisfaction, he is misrepresented by material hunger.
But the foolish leaders cannot see
that even the people who are most sumptuously, materially satisfied are still hungry.
Even the people in rich nations, in rich households, in very powerful, influential, opulent positions, even they are hungry.
So hunger is not for any of those four material needs.
And what is their hunger and poverty?
This Prabhupada explains.
This hunger is actually for spiritual food, for spiritual shelter, for spiritual defense, and spiritual sense gratification.
There are two things.
There is something called material hunger, material food, material shelter, material defense, material sense gratification.
This we all know. We have experience of this.
But there is something else we do not know. What is that? Spiritual food, spiritual shelter, spiritual defense, spiritual sense gratification.
This is something we have to learn from the Bhagavatam.
These can be obtained in the association of the Supreme Spirit, Lord Sri Krishna.
And therefore, one who has them cannot be attracted by so-called food, shelter, defense, and sense gratification of the material world,
even if such material food, shelter, defense, and sense gratification
are relished by the denizens of the heavenly planet.
We may see that somebody else in a relatively higher material position
may be relishing something, apparently, better than what we have with us in terms of material food or material facilities.
But the reality is all living beings in every position in this material world
are hungry for spiritual atmosphere, for spiritual food, spiritual shelter, spiritual defense, spiritual sense gratification.
Therefore, in the Bhagavad Gita 8.16, it is said by the Lord that even in the topmost planet of the universe, namely the Brahmaloka,
what is the situation in Brahmaloka?
In Brahmaloka, the duration of life is multiplied by millions of years by earth calculation.
